6 planets will be visible in the night sky in January, 4 to the naked eye - The National Desk
summary:
Visibility of 6 Planets in January: A Stargazer's Guide

Publication Date: January 2025
Source: WKRC

Nasa has announced that January will be an exciting month for stargazers with six planets visible in the night sky, four of which can be observed without a telescope.

  • Peak of the Quadrantid meteor shower on Jan. 3.
  • The moon will pass in front of Mars on Jan. 13.
  • Venus and Saturn will appear close together on Jan. 17 and 18.
  • The planets visible to the naked eye include Venus, Saturn, Jupiter, and Mars.
  • Uranus and Neptune will require a telescope to be seen.
Nasa states that seeing so many bright planets at once is a notable event.

This January presents a great opportunity for skywatchers, both amateur and experienced, to enjoy the wonders of the night sky.
newTitle: Visibility of 6 Planets in January: A Stargazer's Guide

Nasa is developing new strategies to collect samples from Mars more efficiently and cost-effectively.

  • Collaborations with international partners aim to enhance the mission's feasibility and effectiveness.
  • Cost reduction strategies include using existing infrastructure instead of building new equipment.
  • Timelines for sample collection have been accelerated to expedite research and analysis.

title: NASA Astronaut Captures Stunning Aurora from Space, Sparks Debate on Authenticity - The Hans India
summary:
NASA Astronaut Captures Stunning Aurora from Space, Sparks Debate on Authenticity

Publication Date: October 2023

Source: NASA

Astronaut Donald Pettit, aboard the International Space Station (ISS), shared a captivating 9-second video of auroras that has sparked both admiration and skepticism online. The footage showcases swirling green lights across Earth's atmosphere and went viral, stirring debate about its authenticity.

  • The video captures a mesmerizing view of auroras from space.
  • Some viewers praised the beauty while others questioned its authenticity.
  • Auroras occur due to charged particles from the Sun colliding with atoms in Earth's atmosphere.
“Looks like AI. The Aurora Borealis ebbs and flows and moves around.”

The debate over the video reflects the ongoing fascination with such stunning visuals.
newTitle: NASA Astronaut Captures Stunning Aurora from Space, Sparks Debate on Authenticity

title: Solid-state nuclear clocks brought closer by physical vapour deposition - physicsworld.com
New Fossil Find Rewrites History of Dinosaur Evolution - Sci.News
summary:
New Fossil Find Rewrites History of Dinosaur Evolution

Publication Date: 2025
Source: Sci.News


Paleontologists in the United States have uncovered the fossilized remains of a new species of sauropodomorph dinosaur that lived during the Late Triassic epoch, around 230 million years ago.

  • The new species, named Ahvaytum bahndooiveche, is the oldest known Laurasian dinosaur.
  • It lived in the northern hemisphere during the Carnian age, contemporary with the oldest known southern dinosaurs.
  • Its discovery suggests that dinosaurs may have spread from the northern hemisphere earlier than previously thought.
  • The fossils were found in Wyoming, illustrating a shift in understanding of dinosaur origins.
  • Paleontologist Dr. Dave Lovelace highlights its small size, comparable to a chicken.
“Ahvaytum bahndooiveche lived in Laurasia during or soon after a period of immense climatic change known as the Carnian pluvial episode that has previously been connected to an early period of diversification of dinosaur species.” - Dr. Dave Lovelace

This discovery is significant as it challenges prior hypotheses of dinosaur evolution and dispersal.
newTitle: New Fossil Find Rewrites History of Dinosaur Evolution

summary:
Venus and the Moon Light Up the Night Sky in Gorgeous Photos from Around the World

Publication Date: January 3, 2025

Source: Space.com

The moon and Venus captivated skywatchers worldwide with their conjunction on January 3, 2025. The shining “Evening Star” and a crescent moon were visible together in the night sky, providing breathtaking views and photos from various locations.

  • On January 3, 2025, Venus and a waxing crescent moon created a celestial conjunction visible from many locations.
  • Venus is particularly bright this month, surpassing even Sirius, the brightest star in the sky.
  • Observers in mid-northern latitudes can see Venus for about four hours after sunset throughout January.
  • The conjunction was photographed from multiple locations, including the U.K., Italy, China, France, and Portugal.
Last night's sky was a lovely sight. The Washington Monument was caught between the Moon and Venus, while the unique architecture of the Smithsonian's @NMAAHC glowed along #WashingtonDC's amazing skyline. - U.S. National Park Service

This event encourages people to appreciate the night sky and signifies an opportunity for amateur astronomers to capture stunning photographs of celestial bodies with the right equipment.
newTitle: Venus and the Moon Illuminate the Night Sky with Stunning Photos

title: Dinosaurs may have roamed the northern hemisphere millions of years earlier than previously thought - Phys.org
summary:
Dinosaurs Roamed the Northern Hemisphere Earlier Than Previously Thought

Publication Date: January 8, 2025 | Source: Zoological Journal of the Linnean Society

This article discusses the discovery of a new dinosaur species, Ahvaytum bahndooiveche, whose fossils suggest that dinosaurs were present in the northern hemisphere millions of years earlier than previously believed. This finding challenges long-held views about the geographical emergence of dinosaurs.

  • Ahvaytum bahndooiveche, discovered in Wyoming, is believed to be around 230 million years old, making it the oldest known Laurasian dinosaur.
  • This discovery alters the narrative of dinosaur evolution and migration, suggesting a presence in the northern hemisphere well before previously thought.
  • The research involved collaboration with members of the Eastern Shoshone Tribe, which contributed to the naming of the species.
  • Notably, Ahvaytum bahndooiveche translates to "long ago dinosaur" in the Shoshone language.
  • The fossil evidence was found in a layer of rock that also showcased evidence of a significant climatic change that could have fostered the early diversification of dinosaurs.
"We now have this piece of evidence that shows dinosaurs were here in the northern hemisphere much earlier than we thought." - Dave Lovelace

This discovery not only adds a new chapter to the story of dinosaur migration but also highlights the importance of integrating Indigenous knowledge into scientific research.
newTitle: Dinosaurs Roamed the Northern Hemisphere Earlier Than Previously Thought

China's Chang'e-7 to take payload for making flag flutter on moon - CGTN
summary:
China's Chang'e-7 to make a flag flutter on the moon

Publication Date: January 8, 2025 | Source: CGTN

China's Chang'e-7 mission is set to be launched by 2026, aiming to search for water ice on the moon's south pole. A unique feature of the mission is its educational payload designed to make a flag wave despite the moon's lack of atmosphere.

  • The mission will include an innovative payload inspired by elementary school students.
  • It utilizes electromagnetic interactions to create a waving motion for the flag.
  • Six scientific instruments from various countries will accompany the mission, enhancing international collaboration.
“This initiative is intended to enhance young students' understanding of China's space program and inspire their interest in pursuing space exploration in the future.” - Zhang Tianzhu

This mission represents a step towards engaging the younger generation with space exploration and enhancing China’s presence in lunar research.
newTitle: China's Chang'e-7 to make a flag flutter on the moon

title: World's first wooden satellite sent to Earth's orbit - WION
summary:
World's First Wooden Satellite LignoSat Launched into Orbit

Publication Date: December 2024 | Source: WIONews

The world's first wooden satellite, LignoSat, has been successfully sent into Earth's orbit. Built by Kyoto University in partnership with Sumitomo Forestry, this innovative satellite aims to explore the sustainability of wood in space.

  • LignoSat was launched alongside five CubeSats, reaching a height of 400 km above Earth.
  • The satellite is constructed from 10 cm-long hinoki magnolia wood panels, utilizing a traditional Japanese wood-joinery method that eliminates the need for screws and glue.
  • Weighing approximately 900 grams, LignoSat will investigate wood's performance in space, especially under extreme temperature fluctuations.
  • The mission seeks to assess the feasibility of using wood for future lunar and Mars exploration.
"With timber, a material we can produce by ourselves, we will be able to build houses, live and work in space forever," - Takao Doi, Astronaut

Research conducted during this mission could pave the way for more sustainable manufacturing materials in satellite and space construction.
newTitle: World's First Wooden Satellite LignoSat Launched into Orbit

Real Northern Lights or AI: Intensely green aurora video from NASA astronaut amazes internet. Why are crit - The Economic Times
summary:
Real Northern Lights or AI: Intensely Green Aurora Video from NASA Astronaut Amazes Internet

Publication Date: October 2023 | Source: Panache

A mesmerizing video of an aurora captured by NASA astronaut Don Pettit aboard the International Space Station (ISS) has sparked both awe and debate online. Shared on social media, the video showcases vibrant green hues of the aurora dancing above Earth, a sight often referred to as the Northern Lights. While many praised the breathtaking view, others questioned its authenticity, suggesting it could be a product of artificial intelligence (AI).

  • The nine-second clip, described by Pettit as “intensely green,” features the aurora glowing vividly against a backdrop of city lights visible from space.
  • The video received mixed reactions, with some viewers expressing admiration and others skepticism about its authenticity.
  • Auroras are natural light displays caused by solar particles interacting with Earth’s magnetic field.
  • The debate continues regarding the static appearance of the video and the implications of AI in visual media.
  • Pettit’s experience as a veteran astronaut adds credibility to the video.
“Looks like AI. The Aurora Borealis ebbs and flows and moves around.”

Whether real or digitally enhanced, Pettit’s aurora video has undeniably captivated audiences worldwide.
newTitle: Real Northern Lights or AI: Intensely Green Aurora Video from NASA Astronaut Amazes Internet

‘Real or AI?’: NASA astronaut’s stunning aurora video sparks debate over authenticity - The Indian Express
summary:
‘Real or AI?’: NASA astronaut’s stunning aurora video sparks debate over authenticity

Published on: January 6, 2025 Source: Twitter

A recent video posted by NASA astronaut Don Petit showing an impressive aurora display has provoked debate over its authenticity, with some viewers suggesting the footage might be artificially generated.

  • The video showcases an unusually intense aurora with bright city lights visible in the background.
  • Many viewers expressed skepticism, questioning the proximity of the ISS to Earth and accusing the video of being manipulated.
  • “Flying over aurora; intensely green,” Petit noted in his post about the video.
  • Some viewers praised the beauty of the display while others deemed it “intensely fake,” likening it to artificial intelligence.
  • Auroras are natural light displays caused by charged particles from the sun interacting with Earth’s atmosphere.
“The aurora’s green glow looks unreal from above. Pure magic!”

In conclusion, while the video is visually stunning, the discourse highlights the ongoing tension between appreciating natural phenomena and the skepticism fueled by advancements in technology.
newTitle: NASA Astronaut's Aurora Video Raises Questions on Authenticity

Breakthrough in 2D Material Growth Opens Doors to Cleaner Energy and Next-Generation Technology - AZoNano
summary:
Breakthrough in 2D Material Growth Opens Doors to Cleaner Energy and Next-Generation Technology

Date: October 2023 | Source: University of Surrey

This research decodes the growth process of Hexagonal Boron Nitride (hBN), a 2D material that could enhance electronics and promote cleaner energy solutions.

  • hBN, known as 'white graphene', is ultra-thin and highly resilient.
  • It can protect microchips and improve efficiency in electronics.
  • Nanoporous hBN has been created, with applications in pollution sensing and hydrogen storage.
  • The study was a collaborative effort between the University of Surrey and Graz University of Technology.
  • Research relied on advanced modelling to understand the growth mechanisms of hBN.
Dr Marco Sacchi: “By understanding these mechanisms, we can engineer materials with unprecedented precision.”
Dr Anton Tamtögl: “We believe that it will be useful to guide chemical vapour deposition growth of hBN.”

This breakthrough could lead to significant advancements in various technologies and environmental applications.
newTitle: Breakthrough in 2D Material Growth Opens Doors to Cleaner Energy and Next-Generation Technology

title: Discovery of a Mysterious Substance Beneath Greenland's Glaciers: Predictions of Rising Sea Levels Questioned? - Indian Defence Review
summary:
Discovery of a Mysterious Substance Beneath Greenland's Glaciers: Predictions of Rising Sea Levels Questioned?

Published on: January 8, 2025 | Source: Indian Defence Review

What secrets lie beneath Greenland’s glaciers? This thrilling expedition could reshape our understanding of climate change and rising sea levels. Imagine discovering how hidden sediment mounds might slow down catastrophic glacier retreat.

  • Scientists are exploring the Kangerlussuup glacier in western Greenland to understand its impact on rising sea levels.
  • Led by Professor Ginny Catania from the University of Texas, they are studying sediment mounds at the glacier's base.
  • The research aims to determine if these sediment formations could slow glacier retreat by acting as natural barriers.
  • The expedition uses advanced technology, including a specialized submarine, to navigate treacherous underwater conditions.
  • Findings may significantly alter our understanding of climate change and its geographical impacts.
If Greenland’s ice sheet collapses, we could see sea levels jump by a whopping 23 feet, drastically changing coastlines everywhere.

This groundbreaking expedition highlights the urgency of taking action against climate change. Understanding what lies beneath Greenland's glaciers is vital for future preparation against rising sea levels.
newTitle: Discovery of a Mysterious Substance Beneath Greenland's Glaciers: Predictions of Rising Sea Levels Questioned?

summary:
Millions will be able to see four planets align in the sky with naked eye in rare cosmic event this month

Publication Date: January 2025 | Source: LADBible

This January, astronomy enthusiasts can witness a rare celestial alignment of four planets visible to the naked eye. The planets Venus, Saturn, Jupiter, and Mars will appear together in the night sky, providing a stunning sight for all.

  • The alignment will be particularly visible in rural areas with clear skies.
  • Venus and Jupiter will be the brightest, while Saturn requires a bit more effort to locate.
  • The cosmic event peaks around January 17 and 18.
  • Mercury will not be visible during this alignment.
  • Mars reaches its brightest point on January 16, appearing the furthest east.
“You won't need any specialist equipment or technology either.”

This event is not only a spectacle but also a reminder of the beauty of our night sky—an opportunity for stargazers and casual observers alike to connect with the cosmos.
newTitle: Rare Cosmic Event: Four Planets to Align Visible to the Naked Eye

title: World's first wooden satellite, LignoSat, deployed in space - NewsBytes
summary:
World's First Wooden Satellite, LignoSat, Successfully Deployed in Space

Publication Date: December 2024 | Source: NASA

The world's first wooden satellite, LignoSat, has been successfully deployed into Earth's orbit, representing a significant innovation in satellite technology.

  • LignoSat was placed into Earth's orbit from the International Space Station in December 2024.
  • The project is a collaboration between Kyoto University and Sumitomo Forestry.
  • The satellite is crafted from honoki magnolia wood using a traditional Japanese wood-joinery technique without screws or glue.
  • It weighs only 900 grams and aims to explore the use of wood in space, offering sustainable alternatives to traditional satellite materials.
  • The mission will last six months, during which LignoSat will test resilience against temperature changes and radiation exposure.
  • Wooden satellites could provide a sustainable solution to space debris, burning up upon re-entry into the atmosphere.
"This unique satellite design could change the way future space exploration missions are conducted."

The deployment of LignoSat marks a pivotal moment in both satellite design and space sustainability practices.
newTitle: World's First Wooden Satellite, LignoSat, Successfully Deployed in Space

title: NASA announces new approach to return samples from Mars - BroadcastProME.com
First Wooden Satellite Deployed Into Earth's Orbit, May Transform Space Exploration - NDTV
summary:
First Wooden Satellite Deployed Into Earth's Orbit, May Transform Space Exploration

Publication Date: New Delhi

The world's first wooden satellite LignoSat was among the five CubeSats deployed into Earth's orbit last month, 400 km above the planet. The satellite arrived at the International Space Station in November last year aboard a SpaceX Dragon cargo capsule.

Sensors on board LignoSat will evaluate the strain on wood and its responses to temperature and radiation when orbiting. It is expected to test the feasibility of wood for future lunar and Mars explorations.

  • Developed by Kyoto University and Sumitomo Forestry, LignoSat is made from honoki magnolia wood panels and weighs 900 grams.
  • Its mission will last six months and aims to investigate the use of wood in place of conventional satellite materials.
  • Wood is more durable in space, minimizes environmental impact, and may offer solutions to growing space debris issues.
  • Wooden satellites would burn up upon re-entry, unlike traditional materials that create harmful particles.
“With timber, a material we can produce by ourselves, we will be able to build houses, live and work in space forever.” - Takao Doi

In conclusion, the deployment of LignoSat could signify a revolutionary step in sustainable space exploration.
newTitle: First Wooden Satellite Deployed Into Earth's Orbit, May Transform Space Exploration
